title: $T$ Distribution for Regression
question_text: When performing inference for regression to determine if there is a linear relationship between two variables in a population, which of the following distributions is used?

choices.text: The $t$ distribution with $\text{n } – 1$ degrees of freedom
The chi-square distribution with $\text{n } – 1$ degrees of freedom
The $t$ distribution with $\text{n } – 2$ degrees of freedom
The standard normal distribution with $\text{n } – 2$ degrees of freedom

solution:
Solution

When two quantitative variables are being tested for a linear relationship, the t distribution is used. In addition, the degrees of freedom takes the form n –2, where n is the number of pairs of data in the sample.

So, Choice 'D' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice ‘A’ is incorrect: The t distribution is correct but the degrees of freedom are incorrectly stated. Degrees of freedom n –1 is used for hypothesis tests on the mean of a sample or on the difference between the means of two samples.

Choice ‘B’ is incorrect: The standard normal distribution is used when inference procedures are describing proportions or when the population standard deviation, σ, is known. In most cases, σ will not be known, which is why a hypothesis test is being done in the first place!

Choice ‘C’ is incorrect: The chi-square distribution is used when analyzing data on categorical variables. In order to perform linear regression on data, the data must consist of quantitative variables.

Choice ‘E’ is incorrect: There is only one standard normal distribution. Degrees of freedom are used in other distributions (like the t distribution and the chi-square distribution) in order to select the correct curve, based on sample size, from the family of curves that make up each of those distributions.
